metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
July 23rd.
Dear Sidney,
This morning I received two of the missing letters, No 18 and 19 of July 9th and 1oth.
Is n't it funny the way they go.? Yesterday I received that fast one of the 17th,
In these letters you described the black out was off, and the place sounds very much
on a peace time basis. All this proves to as that Hawaii is less a war zone that London[,]yet I
can go there. It burns me up.
I gather the weather is heaven, the island wonderful but perhaps your job a bit boring[,]
and that you feel sort of remote from the war. I do wish you could be going with me and getting
some of the news I get. I am afraid I have got much the best job. Your sort of work is done here
too and is quite boring. I think your set up is so much like hours it makes me laugh. Too bad
we cant compare notes. You two would fit into my picture like a dream[,]and love it too.
Your next letter I shall get in London[,]and I do hope it wont be a month before it
arrives. I know the first ones will be desperately slow and that I shall be wild, but I shall
try to exert great patience, and "Couer" it to come fast.
Lester was in my office this morning and I read him bitts from your letter. He
loved it. He knows Chief Wilson well and we pat make out why he did not tell us he was in town.
We are both furious.
July 25th.
I never had a chance to get going with this letter and I now in Watch Hill.
I cant believe that I am really not returning to the old Q.Bullding. I said to
everyone goodbye on Saturday, picked up my pessport,and receited the final news
that we were NOT to report to Brooklyn Tuesday. This mean[s]we have been diferred
to some later daye[,] and we have to wait till orders come through from the War Dep.
telling us when to report as I was packed and ready for Watch Hill with the parlor
car reservation in my pocket - I decided I mould not change my plnas again[,]so here
I am with the kids till I am told what to do and where to report. I wired you I
would telephone you Monday night thinking ofcourse I was to be off Tuesday but
now all that is changed. I suppose this may go on for weeks, who knows. However
I deserve a holliday as it is a year now I have been wor[k]ing in Q building so I
think it will all turn out for the best. I hated saying goodbye to my buddies at
the office particularly my pals at the cable desk I have worked with so long. We
have had plenty of work, fun[,]and no end of laughs[,]and I shall miss the old grind
probably inspite of all. I am pretty thrilled at getting off, and think the
future ahead should be both interesting, exciting and different. A real change
from Washington, its heat, its petty jelousies etc. My bags are packed and ready[,]
and Rose has [b]een a wizz as usual listing just what is in every suitcase,and
man[a]ging to have everything in the world I need for every occasion packed just
so. I shall hate to disturb the bags till I arrive over there, however if its a
three weeks trip I shall have to dig in to them a bit. I have brought slacks to
wear on the boat to save clothes, and I am told this is the right idea. I am even
taking powdered eggs, klim milk, vitamin pills, a[1]lb of coffee[,]and some orange
chrystals. Rose bought all this in New York on her shopping tour.
The office gave me a silver identification bracelet with my
[End Page 1]
2
name on it, address American Embassy Grosvenor Square[,]and my blood type. Is n't
that nice? I am delighted with it, and charmed they thought of it,and collected
the money to do it. Pretty sweet.
I left my little house with some regret as it was very cute, but I must say Sat.
morning was such a swelterdng one it was not hard to be pleased to be off for
Rhode Island and the north[,]and shake the heat waves of Washington into the dim
pas .
I read Life and Time all the way up in the train[,]and my the accounts of
Sicily are thrilling[!] It has been better covered than any oper[a]tion so far. Really
swell first hand dope from War Correspondents who f[l]ew in with the paratroopwrs
and got the story from start to finish. It has been a whirlwind campaine, and it
is all going so beautifully it's thrilling. I dont believe the Italians will be
in the war very much longer and I may see Sarah Jane before we know it, at this
rate. As long as wee can put that umbrella of airplanes over the bridge heads
we make,I feel we shall save thousands of lives during the inva_sion. Our air s
strength is super.
Perhaps you and Morris did get into the wrong thing, perhaps the air end
would have got you around much more. I do believe it. Its a shame. I hear Ward
Cheeney is returning from the South P. and Frank is going to ta[k]e my house for
the winter. He is to be stationed there for a while. The air intellegence folks
do get around, and get home quite a lot. None of my freinds have had their husb-
- ands away as long as you have been. Well how could you tell what to do and which
was best? It was a gamble.
Russ Forgan and Ada are up here this week end[,]and I am going to have supper
with than this evening. An english girl here has offered me her house in London
but she admits that it will be hard to find a servant to run it. They are all
in the mun[i]tions factory. I am not going to sign up for anything till I get over
there and see how difficult it all is. I believe a service flat is the thing If
I can possibly find one. I may be there six months or even perhaps 8 .I dont know
- but if the war goes as I think it will[,]I doubt if I am there longer. Also if
you are still in the Pacific by that time[,]there is always a chance things may c
change and I may get out your way. My scouts are out on the look out for me and
I always have hopes.
I understand I can not have any magazenes or newspapers sent to myself in
England which is really too bed. I was hoping Ic could but they wont take the w
weight by sea or air. I think I shall take my radio if I possibly can[,]and am al
-lowed to. My cameras have gone ahead.
I spent a heavenly morning making mud pies on the beach with Bo and Landine
and they are both so brown- I look like a pale lilly beside them. They are both
real brownies, and look the picture of health. What a spot for children! !
Miss Evan[s] manages to have plenty of good food to eat and it is asweet
house, and only five minutes walk to the beach. The house with the tennis court
is across the road from us.
Anita and Eddie Loebkovitz were on the beech this morning,and a million
or more children. It was heaven to be in the sunshine and air, and I wore the w
wonderful white bathing suit of yours with the big red hisbiscus flowers on it.
I thought my midriff looked a bit soft,and white,and naked,but everyone seemd
to think the suit was a knockout. Darling you gave me just what I wanted most.
They arrived Just at the right time for the right occasion. I would ceratinly l
like better to be on your beach wearing them with you, and I would like to see
you in your hawaiian shorts beside me. Do send me a picture of yourself on the
beach. Please.
[End Page 2]
3
You mentined something about having taken some photos several weeks back but I
immggine you forgot about them.
Honolulu myust look very gay with all the bright lights and no curfew.
Really back to noraml and peacetime basis.
No food rationing, and how about gas? Do you get all you want? It
seems unbelievable. I gave my bycicle to a girl in my office till I return, and
Larimer Mellon is using yours. They are so precious one can not afford to be a
dog -in the manger about them.
I am sending you under seperate cover The Times Sunday"New of the week
in Review". It is so good and so infor[m]ative that I hope it reaches you O.K. Do
you ever see the New York papers outnthere? They are so far and away the best.
Armant is in San Pedro.That boy n s nuts who said he sew Armant.It must
have been some other Legendre. Olive is out there with him[,]and the kids right now,
as far as I know, which was a week ago.
I laughed the other day whe  we four girls about to depart were given
a security talk about - from now on saying we had been working all winter in the
State Department,and were no going to work in London for the American Embassy,
because written across the whole top of my pasport is written in plane print
"On special private business for the Office of Strategis Services". Is n't
that a laugh? I love those sort of things. They are so redic_ulous.
Write as I have said before [percent]Amercan Embassy , 1 Grosvenor Square, Londo[n]
as this is adjoining my office, and everyone collects their mail there. 
For"Blitz' I think it will be better for me to say "The duchess came
to tea" as no mention can be made of weather. I know I shall find the sencor
much stricter and I shall have to talk double talk and parabels.
Darling I have real hopes this may all end sooner than we think now,
and that we will see each other sooner than you think. I pray for this constantly
and I believe it too.
Keep your heart under lock and key for me to open with my own key that
great dey on which we meet again. Its a long time my darling,but there is no one
else for me in the world but my Sidney,and I hope you feel that way about your
Gertie who loves you so much. Its a long pull I know,but when we love as we do
we cansurely wait. The world can not keep us apart forever no matter what goes on
in turmoil, strife and endless stretches of separation. I think of you all day
and most of the night[,]and feel so badly about missing so many hours of your
companionship and love. Its a mighty tough assignement for a happy couple. So
many wives and husbands are not happy; not compatible, dont care, and dont feel
the way we do. Its hard on the happily married ones,and those that really care.
Take care of yourself my darling and write me all your news.
I am off to the beech again to fry in the sun and revel in beachlife
I love so much.
I shell write you an other letter to-morrow.
All my love doodle ears.I kiss you and hug you.
Gertrude
[End Page 3]
